Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The Effects of Climate Change on Coral Larvae in Relation to Coral Reef Connectivity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ocean acidification, or OA, is widely recognized as a climate change-related threat to coral reefs. OA may affect processes related to the exchange of free-swimming coral larvae between populations on a reef, and existing research characterizes the importance of seawater flow in transporting these larvae among reefs in order to maintain biodiversity. However, less is known about the position of coral larvae in the water column and how this is affected by OA, representing a critical knowledge gap in evaluating larval dispersal and subsequent connectivity among populations. This project focuses on the behavior and physiology of larvae from a common coral and how these features will be affected by OA. The larger objective is to better understand how OA and climate change will alter connectivity among coral reefs and mediate changes in species composition. The research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Saki Harii at Sesoko Research Station in Okinawa, Japan, as part of the Tropical Biosphere Research Center, University of the Ryukyus.

This project elucidates the effect of ocean acidification (OA) on the early life stages of Pocillopora damicornis, a brooding scleractinian coral, and focuses on the behavior and physiology of their larvae in situ. The project employs a threefold approach that: 1) determines the location of larvae in the water column over a 24-hour period, 2) tests for an effect of OA on behavior of larvae in situ (i.e., position in the water), and 3) examines the effect of parent exposure to OA on larvae behavior. Dr. Harii has successfully conducted many experiments on brooding events, and her expertise will aid in the capture and transport of larvae to experimental in situ chambers. Additionally, the location of Sesoko Research Station will allow for future cross-Pacific comparisons of the physiological performance of P. damicornis larvae under OA, and will be integrated with ongoing experiments conducted in Moorea, French Polynesia, as part of a larger framework of collaboration between researchers in the United States, Japan, and Moorea. Expanding cultural relations between Japan and the United States through the exchange of scientific research will continue to strengthen the academic partnership between the two countries.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My Japanese EAPSI experience provided valuable results toward my masters thesis, which focuses on the effects of ocean acidification on the motility of brooded coral larvae. The majority of the research project was conducted in the lab of my host, Dr. Saki Harii, at Sesoko Station, part of the Tropical Biosphere Research Center at the University of the Ryukyus in Okinawa, Japan. Collaborative technical support, resources, and advisement were also provided by Dr. Haruko Kurihara at the main campus of the University. The EAPSI provided a unique opportunity to conduct an experiment in situ, as well as take a novel approach to my question using laboratory techniques outside of the scope of my home institution.

The broader purpose of this experiment was to contribute to the existing knowledge of the projected effects of ocean acidification (OA), a climate change-related threat to coral reefs, on free-swimming baby corals. This project tested the hypothesis that, due to the sensitivity of coral larvae to extreme environmental conditions, OA will perturb larval motility. Experiments focused on behavior and physiology of larvae from the coral Pocillopora damicornis using in situ incubations on the reefs of Okinawa, where freshly released larvae were exposed to ambient and elevated pCO2. By scoring larval position at both ambient and high pCO2 in acrylic tubes vertically oriented in the water column, I observed a quantifiable change in larval behavior at high pCO2. Additionally, I measured a decline in lipid content of larvae at high pCO2. The results of this experiment imply that the vertical orientation of coral larvae will be altered under OA conditions, which has implications for the dispersal of corals among reefs in the future.

The EAPSI program broadened my perspectives on the value of international research and cultural enrichment, as well as built on an already strong existing collaborative relationship between my university (CSUN) and Sesoko Station. Post-EAPSI, I presented my results at the 2016 Western Society of Naturalists meeting in Monterey, CA. Additionally, I had the opportunity to return to Japan and present the results of my summer's research to my collaborators and other peers in the field at the 2016 Japanese Coral Reef Society Annual Meeting in Okinawa. The research conducted via the EAPSI program is currently being compiled into a manuscript and is in preparation for publication.

Through the EAPSI program, I was able to build a strong and ongoing relationship with my international collaborators, and plan to disseminate the benefits of research abroad to my peers and fellow graduate students at CSUN to work toward continually increasing global awareness in scientific research.
